articles.headline: N.R.A. Envisions ‘a Good Guy With a Gun’ in Every School
articles.snippet: After a weeklong silence, the National Rifle Association implicated violent video games, the news media and lax law enforcement — not guns — in a rash of mass shootings.
articles.abstract: After a weeklong silence, the National Rifle Association implicated violent video games, the news media and lax law enforcement — not guns — in a rash of mass shootings.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a weeklong silence, the National Rifle Association announced Friday that it wants to arm security officers at every school in the country. It pointed the finger at violent video games, the news media and lax law enforcement — not guns — as culprits in the recent rash of mass shootings.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Motoko Rich

articles.headline: Engineered Fish Moves a Step Closer to Approval
articles.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration concluded that a genetically engineered salmon would have “no significant impact” on the environment.
articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration concluded that a genetically engineered salmon would have “no significant impact” on the environment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Government regulators moved a big step closer on Friday to allowing the first genetically engineered animal — a fast-growing salmon — to enter the nation’s food supply.

articles.headline: Revisiting Apple, NBC and Gay Marriage
articles.snippet: As 2013 approaches, an update on some topics from 2012: the success of “The Voice,” a North Carolina businessman’s stand for gay marriage and whither Apple?
articles.abstract: As 2013 approaches, an update on some topics from 2012: the success of “The Voice,” a North Carolina businessman’s stand for gay marriage and whither Apple?
articles.lead_paragraph: After Apple introduced its iPhone 5 in China last week, Apple’s chief executive, Tim Cook, hailed the rollout as the company’s most successful ever, with two million handsets sold the first weekend. It’s the kind of news that in the past has sent Apple stock soaring.

articles.headline: Retailers Try to Adapt to Device-Hopping Shoppers
articles.snippet: Online merchants are trying to figure out how to tie together the several methods a customer may use on the way to buying something.
articles.abstract: Online merchants are trying to figure out how to tie together the several methods a customer may use on the way to buying something.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ryan O’Neil, a Connecticut government employee, was in the market to buy a digital weather station this month. His wife researched options on their iPad, but even though she found the lowest-price option there, Mr. O’Neil made the purchase on his laptop.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Stephanie Clifford

articles.headline: Walking the Tightrope on Mental Health Coverage
articles.snippet: While many people with health insurance also have mental health coverage, some are reluctant to use it — or can’t find a practitioner who will accept it.
articles.abstract: While many people with health insurance also have mental health coverage, some are reluctant to use it — or can’t find a practitioner who will accept it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Insurance covers more mental health care than many people may realize, and more people will soon have the kind of health insurance that does so. But coverage goes only so far when there aren’t enough practitioners who accept it — or there aren’t any nearby, or they aren’t taking any new patients.

articles.headline: Instagram Reversal Doesn’t Appease Everyone
articles.snippet: Even as the social network furiously backpedaled on its proposal to change its privacy terms, some users said they were carrying through on plans to leave.
articles.abstract: Even as the social network furiously backpedaled on its proposal to change its privacy terms, some users said they were carrying through on plans to leave.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook may have quelled a full-scale rebellion by quickly dumping the contentious new terms of use for Instagram, its photo-sharing service. But even as the social network furiously backpedaled, some users said Friday they were carrying through on plans to leave.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: In Taxes, Guns and Cabinet, Gridlock Grips the Capital
articles.snippet: An opposition still bitter about President Obama’s victory is unwilling to bend  on social policy, economics or foreign affairs, severely limiting the president.
articles.abstract: An opposition still bitter about President Obama’s victory is unwilling to bend  on social policy, economics or foreign affairs, severely limiting the president.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If Friday’s memorial service for one of this country’s long-serving senators was a somber recollection of a bipartisan era that once was, the rest of the day was a frenetic reminder of the political gridlock that now grips the capital.

articles.headline: The War Against Too Much of Everything
articles.snippet: Kalle Lasn of Adbusters magazine, who helped create Occupy Wall Street, is taking on what he sees as overconsumption of all kinds, most recently with a “Buy Nothing Christmas” campaign.
articles.abstract: Kalle Lasn of Adbusters magazine, who helped create Occupy Wall Street, is taking on what he sees as overconsumption of all kinds, most recently with a “Buy Nothing Christmas” campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: IF you haven’t finished your holiday shopping yet, don’t bother.

articles.headline: In Ravaged Syria, Beach Town May Be Loyalists’ Last Resort
articles.snippet: The resort town of Tartus is seen as a possible place for Alawites, including President Bashar al-Assad, to establish a rump state if the government falls.
articles.abstract: The resort town of Tartus is seen as a possible place for Alawites, including President Bashar al-Assad, to establish a rump state if the government falls.
articles.lead_paragraph: TARTUS, Syria — Loyalists who support the government of President Bashar al-Assad are flocking to the Mediterranean port of Tartus, creating an overflowing boomtown far removed from the tangled, scorched rubble that now mars most Syrian cities.
articles.byline: By An Employee of The New York Times in Syria and Neil MacFarquhar

articles.headline: As Charter Nears Passage, Egyptians Face New Fights
articles.snippet: An Islamist-backed constitution appeared to be headed for approval, propelling deeply split political factions into a new phase in the battle over Egypt’s future.
articles.abstract: An Islamist-backed constitution appeared to be headed for approval, propelling deeply split political factions into a new phase in the battle over Egypt’s future.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Mayy El Sheikh

articles.headline: A 2013 Guide to Better Behavior in Business
articles.snippet: Here’s a wish list for what might bring happiness to United States investors, taxpayers, home buyers and consumers in the new year.
articles.abstract: Here’s a wish list for what might bring happiness to United States investors, taxpayers, home buyers and consumers in the new year.
articles.lead_paragraph: AS the new year draws near, I’ve been thinking about what might make it a happy one for investors, taxpayers, home buyers and consumers. Herewith, a short wish list:

articles.headline: A Fascination of Wall St., and Investigators
articles.snippet: Interviews paint a complex portrait of Steven A. Cohen, the billionaire whose firm, SAC Capital, once employed several people whom a government inquiry has linked to insider trading.
articles.abstract: Interviews paint a complex portrait of Steven A. Cohen, the billionaire whose firm, SAC Capital, once employed several people whom a government inquiry has linked to insider trading.
articles.lead_paragraph: YOU want the headquarters of Steven A. Cohen, one of the most successful financial speculators of our time, to look like Dr. Evil’s secret lair. But it is just another office-park building, a low-slung affair of tinted glass and red brick, on the southern fringes of Stamford, Conn.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson, Peter Lattman and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Giving Mom’s Book Five Stars? Amazon May Cull Your Review
articles.snippet: Amazon’s decision to delete thousands of book reviews has generated an uproar, but the company has not offered a public explanation for the sweeping purge.
articles.abstract: Amazon’s decision to delete thousands of book reviews has generated an uproar, but the company has not offered a public explanation for the sweeping purge.
articles.lead_paragraph: Giving raves to family members is no longer acceptable. Neither is writers’ reviewing other writers. But showering five stars on a book you admittedly have not read is fine.

articles.headline: How Party of Budget Restraint Shifted to ‘No New Taxes,’ Ever
articles.snippet: Some Republicans fear that the party’s commitment to prevent tax increases more and more is coming at the expense of those other, older kinds of fiscal responsibility.
articles.abstract: Some Republicans fear that the party’s commitment to prevent tax increases more and more is coming at the expense of those other, older kinds of fiscal responsibility.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On a Saturday afternoon in October 1990, Senator Pete V. Domenici turned from a conversation on the Senate floor, caught the eye of a clerk by raising his right hand and voted in favor of a huge and contentious bill to reduce federal deficits. Then he put his hand back into his pocket and returned to the conversation.

articles.headline: Buying Back Greek Debt Rewarded Hedge Funds
articles.snippet: To some experts, the latest chapter in the Greek fiscal drama is a new reminder of how private investors have managed to outmaneuver Europe’s officials at various stages of the debt crisis.
articles.abstract: To some experts, the latest chapter in the Greek fiscal drama is a new reminder of how private investors have managed to outmaneuver Europe’s officials at various stages of the debt crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Last month, the European Commission’s top economic official in Brussels, Olli Rehn, received an intriguing e-mail.

articles.headline: For the Holidays, Hong Kong Decks Its Skyscrapers in Lights
articles.snippet: Owners of dozens of buildings across the city drape the exteriors with enormous displays for Christmas, New Year and the Lunar New Year — an expense that appears to be downturn-proof.
articles.abstract: Owners of dozens of buildings across the city drape the exteriors with enormous displays for Christmas, New Year and the Lunar New Year — an expense that appears to be downturn-proof.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — For the past few weeks, Santa Claus, looking cheerful and surrounded by twinkling stars and ornaments, has been dancing on the sides of skyscrapers.

articles.headline: No Sales Pop for a New Version of Windows
articles.snippet: Weak PC sales this holiday season suggest the struggles of Microsoft and other companies that depend heavily on the computer business will not abate soon.
articles.abstract: Weak PC sales this holiday season suggest the struggles of Microsoft and other companies that depend heavily on the computer business will not abate soon.
articles.lead_paragraph: BELLEVUE, Wash. — It used to be that a new version of the Windows operating system was enough to get people excited about buying a new computer, giving sales a nice pop.

articles.headline: Little Sign of a Predicted E-Book Price War
articles.snippet: After a Justice Department investigation into e-book price-fixing, the cost of buying an e-book was supposed to plunge, but sales of e-readers and the content for them have stalled.
articles.abstract: After a Justice Department investigation into e-book price-fixing, the cost of buying an e-book was supposed to plunge, but sales of e-readers and the content for them have stalled.
articles.lead_paragraph: Right about now, just as millions of e-readers and tablets are being slipped under Christmas trees, there was supposed to be a ferocious price war over e-books.

articles.headline: Hollywood Rebounds at the Box Office
articles.snippet: New characters — Katniss Everdeen, Ted the foul-mouthed bear — and familiar ones lifted North American ticket sales in 2012.
articles.abstract: New characters — Katniss Everdeen, Ted the foul-mouthed bear — and familiar ones lifted North American ticket sales in 2012.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Some blockbuster new characters — Katniss Everdeen, Ted the foul-mouthed bear — joined some familiar ones (Batman, Bond, Baggins) to deliver a lift to moviegoing in North America in 2012, increasing attendance by 5.6 percent after two years of declines.

articles.headline: A TV Voice Rang True in Clamor of Shooting
articles.snippet: John Miller of CBS News was a constant figure in the coverage of the shootings in Newtown, Conn., bringing a rare level of seriousness to a story that brought out the worst in television news.
articles.abstract: John Miller of CBS News was a constant figure in the coverage of the shootings in Newtown, Conn., bringing a rare level of seriousness to a story that brought out the worst in television news.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the day of the school shooting in Newtown, Conn., reporters were struggling and failing to get their arms around a story too horrible to fathom. At our house, we stared at the incremental television coverage and came to realize that no one really knew anything.

articles.headline: All the World’s a Game, and Business Is a Player
articles.snippet: Many businesses are using gamification to get people hooked on their products and services — and it is working, thanks to smartphones and the Internet.
articles.abstract: Many businesses are using gamification to get people hooked on their products and services — and it is working, thanks to smartphones and the Internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: Congratulations. Reading the first paragraph of this article has earned you a badge.

articles.headline: A Campaign on U.S. Debt Gains Steam
articles.snippet: Maya MacGuineas is the face of the Campaign to Fix the Debt, a nonpartisan coalition of chief executives, politicians and economic experts lobbying lawmakers to broker a deal.
articles.abstract: Maya MacGuineas is the face of the Campaign to Fix the Debt, a nonpartisan coalition of chief executives, politicians and economic experts lobbying lawmakers to broker a deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Maya MacGuineas has been ringing alarms about the nation’s growing debt for 15 years, imagining a day when a president and a Congress might finally work together to curb deficit spending. After watching President Obama and Speaker John A. Boehner once again come close to agreeing on a plan, only to see a deal slip away, she is troubled but undeterred.

articles.headline: Search for Way Through Fiscal Impasse Turns to the Senate
articles.snippet: With little more than a week left to avert huge tax increases and spending cuts, attention moved to the less polarized chamber, where several Republicans openly back an agreement.
articles.abstract: With little more than a week left to avert huge tax increases and spending cuts, attention moved to the less polarized chamber, where several Republicans openly back an agreement.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With little more than a week for lawmakers to avert huge tax increases and spending cuts, attention is turning from the gridlocked House to the Senate, where some Republicans on Sunday endorsed President Obama’s call for a partial deal to insulate most Americans from the tax increases but defer a resolution on spending.

articles.headline: Citing Broken System, Critics Fight Russia’s Adoption Ban
articles.snippet: Critics say a ban on adoptions by Americans would end up further fraying a disastrously overwhelmed foster care and orphanage system in Russia.
articles.abstract: Critics say a ban on adoptions by Americans would end up further fraying a disastrously overwhelmed foster care and orphanage system in Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The orphans’ faces can be called up on screen, their photos the size of postage stamps, along with a few data points and a note about their personalities, often just a word or two.

articles.headline: Rebuilding in Haiti Lags After Billions in Post-Quake Aid
articles.snippet: Despite billions of dollars spent — and billions more allocated for Haiti but unspent — rebuilding has barely begun and 357,785 Haitians still languish in 496 tent camps.
articles.abstract: Despite billions of dollars spent — and billions more allocated for Haiti but unspent — rebuilding has barely begun and 357,785 Haitians still languish in 496 tent camps.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — A few days after the Jan. 12, 2010, earthquake, Reginald Boulos opened the gates of his destroyed car dealership to some 14,000 displaced people who settled on the expansive property. Seven months later, eager to rebuild his business, he paid the families $400 each to leave Camp Boulos and return to their devastated neighborhoods.
